name: Bhai Banno
birthPlace: Village Mangat (also known as Khara Mangat), Phalia tahsil, Gujrat district, Punjab region (present-day Pakistan)
excerpt: Bhai Banno was a prominent Sikh devotee and contemporary of Guru Arjan Dev and Guru Hargobind. He played a key role in the early dissemination of the Adi Granth by assisting in its transportation for binding and creating an authorized copy, known as the Bhai Banno Vali Bir, which he installed in his village. His efforts helped preserve and propagate Sikh scriptures during a formative period.

quickStats.value: Copying and installation of the Adi Granth

quickFacts.label: Role in Sikh History
quickFacts.value: Assisted in construction of Harmandir Sahib and early scripture preservation

biographySections.label: Early Life
biographySections.value: Bhai Banno was born into a devout family in the village of Mangat, also referred to as Khara Mangat, in the Phalia tahsil of Gujrat district (now in Pakistan). His father, Bhai Bishan Dev, instilled in him a strong religious disposition from an early age. Growing up in the Punjab region during the 16th century, Bhai Banno imbibed Sikh values and became a committed Sikh under the spiritual guidance of the early Gurus. Historical accounts describe him as diligent and pious, traits that defined his lifelong service to the Sikh community [SikhiWiki Reference].

biographySections.label: Contributions/Service
biographySections.value: Bhai Banno's most significant contributions occurred during the era of Guru Arjan Dev. He rendered dedicated service during the construction of the Harmandir Sahib (Golden Temple) in Amritsar, contributing to its physical and spiritual development. In 1604, following the compilation of the Adi Granth (the precursor to the Guru Granth Sahib), Guru Arjan entrusted Bhai Banno with the sacred duty of transporting the original manuscript to Lahore for professional binding. With the Guru's permission, he first took it to his village, where he meticulously prepared an exact copy of the Granth. He then proceeded to Lahore, had both volumes bound, and returned them to the Guru. The original Adi Bir was installed in the Harmandir Sahib, while Bhai Banno received his copy, which became known as the "Bhai Banno Vali Bir" or "Khare Vali Bir." He installed this copy in his family home in Khara Mangat, making it a center for Sikh worship and learning. Throughout his life, Bhai Banno preached Sikh tenets across the northwestern Punjab, fostering the growth of the faith in rural areas [Cross-verified from SikhiWiki and historical texts; Wikipedia mentions in broader Sikh history pages, no dedicated article].

biographySections.label: Key Reforms
biographySections.value: N/A (Bhai Banno was not a reformer in the institutional sense but supported Guru Arjan's efforts in standardizing Sikh scripture, which was a pivotal reform in unifying Sikh doctrine and preventing interpolations).

biographySections.label: Compositions/Writings
biographySections.value: Bhai Banno is not credited with original compositions in the Guru Granth Sahib. His primary "writing" was the faithful transcription of the Adi Granth, ensuring its accurate replication. The Bhai Banno Vali Bir, while a copy, includes some debated additions (e.g., certain raags or hymns not in the standard Kartarpuri Bir), but these are considered later interpolations rather than his original work. Scholars note that his copy served as an early reference text for Sikh communities [Citation needed for specific interpolations; referenced in Sikh historical studies].

biographySections.label: Final Years
biographySections.value: In his later years, Bhai Banno continued to propagate Sikh teachings in the Punjab region, particularly in villages around Gujrat and Lahore. He passed away in January 1645 (Magh 1701 Bikrami) at the age of approximately 87, leaving a legacy of scriptural preservation. His family home in Khara Mangat remained a site of reverence for the installed Bir until historical upheavals, including the Partition of India [SikhiWiki; cross-checked with Bhai Banno Darpan by Rajinder Singh Bal].

spiritualLegacy.description: Bhai Banno's legacy lies in his role as a custodian of Sikh scripture, embodying the Sikh principle of selfless service (seva) and devotion to the Guru. By creating and safeguarding an early copy of the Adi Granth, he ensured the wider dissemination of Guru Nanak's teachings during a time when Sikhism was emerging amid Mughal persecution. His actions exemplified the Sikh ethos of preserving Gurbani for future generations, influencing the standardization of the Guru Granth Sahib under later Gurus.
keyContributions: Assisted in the physical construction of Harmandir Sahib, symbolizing the establishment of Sikh sacred spaces.
Transported and copied the Adi Granth, enabling its installation and study beyond Amritsar.
Preached Sikhism in rural Punjab, strengthening community ties and devotion.

modernRelevance.description: In contemporary Sikhism, Bhai Banno is remembered as a symbol of scholarly dedication and the importance of accurate scriptural transmission. His story highlights the risks and devotion involved in preserving religious texts during turbulent times. The Bhai Banno Vali Bir, though not canonical today, is studied by historians for insights into early Sikh manuscript variations.
contemporaryImpact: Influences discussions on Sikh textual history in academic circles, such as at the Shiromani Gurdwara Parbandhak Committee (SGPC).
Inspires modern initiatives for digitizing and preserving Gurbani, echoing his role in early copying efforts.
Commemorated in Sikh literature and gurdwaras, promoting values of seva and historical awareness.

historicalContext.period: Late 16th to early 17th century (Mughal-Sikh era, post-Guru Nanak).
historicalContext.politicalSituation: Under Mughal Emperor Jahangir, Sikhs faced increasing scrutiny; Guru Arjan's martyrdom in 1606 marked rising tensions, but Bhai Banno's work predated this, occurring during relative stability under Akbar's tolerant policies.
historicalContext.socialConditions: Rural Punjab was agrarian with diverse religious influences (Hindu, Muslim, Sikh). Sikhism was consolidating as a distinct faith, emphasizing equality and scripture-based devotion amid caste rigidities and conversions.
historicalContext.significance: Bhai Banno's efforts supported the centralization of Sikh identity around the Granth, crucial for its survival against future persecutions. His copy aided local worship, democratizing access to Gurbani beyond urban centers [Cross-verified; citation needed for exact political ties to Jahangir's reign].
